poem:
Title: "A Messenger in the Oaks"

Westward the pied flycatchers roam,
A feathered ballet 'neath the forest dome,
Thinly spread from Cornwall's stone,
To Caithness where seabirds moan.
In Derbyshire scarce, Herefordshire's pride,
Two dozen sightings at morning-tide.
Nestling amid summer's tender kiss,
An avian narrative, nature's bliss.
Marked and paired, in the ringing project,
An astounding sight, nature's subject.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Country diary: These summer migrants are remarkable | Mark Cocker Pied flycatchers are summer migrants largely attached to the oakwoods of western Britain and thinly spread from Cornwall to Caithness. In Derbyshire, I’m lucky if I encounter them half a dozen times, so to see 24 in a morning signals that this Herefordshire site is very special. There are 30 pairs all in nest boxes and all part of a ringing project. Even more remarkable is". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
